body.p: On reading the article ‘Thermal anomaly detection in datacenters’ by Yuan et al.1 in a recent issue of this journal, I have the following points to make. There is, in the paper, frequent reference to ‘temperature sensors’ and heavy reliance on the readings of such sensors in the discussion. What sort of ‘sensors’ were they? I should think that they must have been either thermocouples or resistance temperature detectors (RTDs). I have put ‘thermocouple’, ‘RTD’ and ‘resistance’ into the Find facility of the online version of the paper and obtained a nil result in each case. This information needs to be supplied.

I am in the dark about the ‘thermal drift’ of the sensors referred to on page 2114. Thermocouples and RTDs if working properly do not ‘drift’: they go on measuring whatever temperature they are experiencing. So this too needs explanation for the benefit of readers.

ref.citation: YuanYLeeEKPompiliD. Thermal anomaly detection in datacenters. Proc IMechE, Part C: J Mechanical Engineering Science 2012; 226(8): 2104–2117.
